Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Rapid 3D printing in gel suspension
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop a 3D printer technology capable of printing complex geometries in a suspended environment at high speed. The printing technology directly writes in 3D space using a gel suspension bath. The gel provides a zero-gravity environment, eliminating the need for support material and allows for the printing of highly complex overhanging geometries with high-quality surface finishes. The gel bath is a non-toxic, water-based formulation. Printed objects are simply washed off once printed, requiring no post-processing. The gel can be reused indefinitely. The team believes the automotive, aviation, furniture, childrenâ€™s product and medical industries could integrate the printing capabilities in their manufacturing process near term. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a technology that enables access to a high-speed 3D printer technology capable of printing fully rigid and flexible industrial grade materials at infinite scale. Currently, 3D printers are limited by poor material quality, small build volume, and slow speed; hence current 3D printers are generally only used as prototyping tools. This project may improve and provide new manufacturing techniques for complex geometries, casting, and molding. This new way of manufacturing may drastically reduce production cost for molded parts, while increasing machine efficiency. The project has the potential to expand the 3D printing market by allowing for mass customization while streamlining traditional manufacturing processes. The team will simultaneously integrate with existing material supply chains and work with companies to locate new products and markets.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF I-Corps award provided the framework and training to understand the potential applications, customers and key value propositions of a new technology that can have global impact on manufacturing.  The technology is a novel, patented, support and structure-free elastomer manufacturing process that combines the capabilities of traditional manufacturing and 3D printing solutions. Through our unique process, parts are suspended within a safe, reusable gel-build medium, eliminating the effects of gravity and avoiding restrictions of the typical multi-layer approach for non-planar printing. Designs that traditionally take hours or weeks to manufacture are able to be produced in minutes using this Rapid Liquid Print (RLP) technology. The RLP process allows for the direct manufacture of complex parts, which are impossible to make through all other methods. 

During the initial 7 week training, the team conducted an intensive customer discovery and interview process accomplishing more than 100 interviews with potential customers. This process was continued after the conclusion of the national cohort with a great many more customer interviews for discovery and validation.
Given RLP.?s ability to print with medical grade silicone and at speeds 100 times faster than traditional manufacturing processes, we quickly focused on the prosthetic market. Using individualized digital files of patients? actual limbs, our technology direct prints custom prosthetic liners without the use of expensive tooling or molding found in traditional manufacturing.  Our technology produced custom liners more affordably for patients and more importantly allowed them to get back on their feet faster.

This led to the formation of a startup, Rapid Liquid Print, Inc., to commercialize this 3D printing technology. By the end of this award, the startup employed 6  full time staff and raised over $2 million in venture capital investments. 

Today, RLP. continues to print for prosthetic companies and are expanding business efforts to collaborate with automotive and footwear companies as well. Most recently, RLP has sold an early printing machine to a prosthetic company. and are ramping up our fundraising efforts over the next few months in continuation of the success and growth of the company.

The team has successfully begun to commercialize the technology with revenue from customers for products and services. As the team continues to develop further advances and capabilities for 3D printing of complex geometries at high speed within a gelsuspension bath that provides a zero-gravity environment, many more practical applications and solutions will become possible. The team views the skills acquired from training provided during this project as critical factors in achieving these objectives by building products that actually address a market need and getting the products into practical use.

The team has seen first hand  how our technology is unlocking new possibilities that are currently impossible with any other manufacturing processes. The team believes the automotive, aviation, furniture, children?s product and medical industries could integrate the printing capabilities in their manufacturing process near term.

This project may improve and provide new manufacturing techniques for complex geometries, casting, and molding. This new way of manufacturing may drastically reduce production cost for molded parts, while increasing machine efficiency. The project has the potential to expand the 3D printing market by allowing for mass customization while streamlining traditional manufacturing processes.


Last Modified: 11/25/2022
Modified by: Roman Lubynsky

The technology is a novel, patented, support and structure-free elastomer manufacturing process that combines the capabilities of traditional manufacturing and 3D printing solutions. Through our unique process, parts are suspended within a safe, reusable gel-build medium, eliminating the effects of gravity and avoiding restrictions of the typical multi-layer approach for non-planar printing. Designs that traditionally take hours or weeks to manufacture are able to be produced in minutes using this Rapid Liquid Print (RLP) technology. The RLP process allows for the direct manufacture of complex parts, which are impossible to make through all other methods. During the initial 7 week training, the team conducted an intensive customer discovery and interview process accomplishing more than 100 interviews with potential customers. This process was continued after the conclusion of the national cohort with a great many more customer interviews for discovery and validation. Given RLP.?s ability to print with medical grade silicone and at speeds 100 times faster than traditional manufacturing processes, we quickly focused on the prosthetic market. Using individualized digital files of patients? actual limbs, our technology direct prints custom prosthetic liners without the use of expensive tooling or molding found in traditional manufacturing. Our technology produced custom liners more affordably for patients and more importantly allowed them to get back on their feet faster. This led to the formation of a startup, Rapid Liquid Print, Inc., to commercialize this 3D printing technology. By the end of this award, the startup employed 6 full time staff and raised over $2 million in venture capital investments. Today, RLP. continues to print for prosthetic companies and are expanding business efforts to collaborate with automotive and footwear companies as well. The team has successfully begun to commercialize the technology with revenue from customers for products and services. As the team continues to develop further advances and capabilities for 3D printing of complex geometries at high speed within a gelsuspension bath that provides a zero-gravity environment, many more practical applications and solutions will become possible. The team views the skills acquired from training provided during this project as critical factors in achieving these objectives by building products that actually address a market need and getting the products into practical use. The team has seen first hand how our technology is unlocking new possibilities that are currently impossible with any other manufacturing processes. The team believes the automotive, aviation, furniture, children?s product and medical industries could integrate the printing capabilities in their manufacturing process near term. This project may improve and provide new manufacturing techniques for complex geometries, casting, and molding. This new way of manufacturing may drastically reduce production cost for molded parts, while increasing machine efficiency. The project has the potential to expand the 3D printing market by allowing for mass customization while streamlining traditional manufacturing processes.
